--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Elliotte Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> Every public method added to a class expands the complexity of the
class 
> more than linearly. Every public class added to a library expands the 
> complexity of the library more than linearly. Usable APIs need to place 
> the needs of the user ahead of the needs of the original developer. 

And that's why you distinguish between "public" and "published", Elliotte.

This is why you can provide an "API" jar and a "runtime" jar. This is
why you provide a list of packages to JavaDoc. And this is why you
make it clear that people deviate from your API to use the
implementation-dependent aspects at their own risk.

Heck, as you said later, this is also what package-private is for. As
I've stated earlier, I use a default of package private when I extract
a new "public" class.

Robert.
